# Exchange Fund

- Auditor-in-Charge's Report
- Exchange Fund Financial Statements

# Auditor-in-Charge's Report

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I confirm that I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group") set out on pages 167 to 273. These financial statements include the balance sheet of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2018, and the income and expenditure accounts, comprehensive income statements, changes in equity statements, and cash flow statements for the year ended on that date, together with the notes to the financial statements, including summaries of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, these financial statements fairly present the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2018, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the Hong Kong Accounting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and have been prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66).

# Basis of the Opinion

The audit was conducted in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the Audit Office's audit standards. My responsibilities relating to the audit of the financial statements are detailed in the section entitled "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements" in this report. Under those standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with those standards. I believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to support my audit opinion.

# Critical Audit Matters

Critical audit matters are those areas that, in my professional judgment, were most significant in the audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2018. I addressed these matters in conducting the overall audit and forming my opinion, but I do not express a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.5, 2.6 and 40.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2018, the Group had financial assets measured at fair value amounting to HK$369,358.9 billion and financial liabilities measured at fair value amounting to HK$113,382.9 billion.

93% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were valued based on quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 inputs) or estimated using valuation methodologies where the inputs were based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The remaining 7% of these financial assets were valued using valuation methodologies where the inputs were not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets amounted to HK$27,563.1 billion, primarily comprising non-listed investment funds.

Given the large amounts involved and the nature of the estimates, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value constitutes a critical audit matter.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value included:

- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including related control measures;
- Evaluating and testing control measures, including application controls over computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmation regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices from independent sources if market quotations were used;
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and whether the assumptions were reasonable, and verifying the inputs from independent sources if the inputs were based on observable market data; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable, if the inputs were not based on observable market data.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.12, 20 and 21 to the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties are measured at fair value, amounting to HK$2,532.1 billion as at 31 December 2018. The Group also holds interests in three associate companies and 20 joint ventures, which mainly engage in holding overseas investment properties, with the interests amounting to HK$4,433.6 billion. Whether held directly by the Group or through associate or joint ventures, the fair values of these investment properties are primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:

- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or through associate or joint ventures, and verifying that the fair values were determined based on the valuations stated in those reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable.

# Other Information

The Chief Executive is responsible for other information. Other information includes all information contained in the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority for 2018, but does not include the financial statements or my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion on other information.

In relation to the audit of the financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information in order to consider whether other information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or with information known during the audit, or appears to contain material misstatements. If, based on the work I have performed, I conclude that other information contains material misstatements, I would need to report this fact. In this regard, I have no such reports.

# Responsibilities of the Chief Executive and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in Respect of the Financial Statements

The Chief Executive is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Accounting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing internal controls that the Chief Executive considers necessary to prevent material misstatements in the financial statements due to fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Chief Executive is responsible for assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclosing matters relating to going concern where applicable, and using going concern as the basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for monitoring the Group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the overall financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report containing my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot ensure that the audit carried out in accordance with the Audit Office's audit standards will detect any material misstatement that may exist. Material misstatements can arise from fraud or error, and would be considered material if individually or in the aggregate, they could influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit carried out in accordance with the Audit Office's audit standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism. I will also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements arising from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omission, false representation, or override of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements arising from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those arising from errors;
- Understand the internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not constitute an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal control;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Chief Executive are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the use of going concern as the basis of accounting by the Chief Executive is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are any material uncertainties relating to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that there are material uncertainties, it is necessary to draw the attention of users to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements. If the relevant disclosures are insufficient, I must issue an auditor's report with a qualified opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained as of the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including disclosure, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to form an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising and performing the audit of the Group. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the planned audit and major audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee indicating that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate all relationships and other matters that I reasonably believe may affect my independence, and in the applicable cases, the relevant safeguards.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I will determine which matters are most important for the audit of the current financial statements, and thus constitute critical audit matters. I will describe these matters in the auditor's report, unless legal or regulatory restrictions prevent public disclosure of a particular matter, or in exceptional rare circumstances, where there is a reasonable expectation that communicating the matter in my report would result in negative consequences outweighing the public interest, and I decide not to communicate the matter in the report.

Auditor-in-Charge
Chu Nai-chang

4 April 2019
